questions.text: A patient presents with sudden diminution of vision, difficulty looking towards the light, and circumcorneal congestion with a hypopyon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Acute anterior uveitis:

  • The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of acute anterior uveitis. The presence of a hypopyon is often seen in conditions like Behcet disease, which can typically cause non-granulomatous anterior uveitis.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C do not present with a hypopyon.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with blurred vision, photophobia, and mild ocular pain. Examination reveals aqueous flares and keratic precipitates in the anterior chamber. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Iridocyclitis

Explanation:

Type of Uveitis

Signs

Anterior (Option D)

Granulomatous iridocyclitis, iris nodules, large mutton fat KPs, anterior chamber cells and flare, posterior synechiae

Intermediate (Option A)

Vitreous cells, snowball opacities, snowbanking

Posterior (Option B)

Choroidal and retinal granulomas, cystoid macular edema, periphlebitis retinae with candle wax droppings appearance

Peripheral Multifocal Chorioretinitis

Small, punched-out atrophic spots, highly suggestive of sarcoidosis

Uveoparotid Fever (Heerfordt’s Syndrome)

Bilateral granulomatous panuveitis, painful parotid gland enlargement, cranial nerve palsies, skin rashes, fever, malaise

Toxoplasma uveitis (Option C):

  • Definitive host: Cat; Intermediate host: Human
  • Ocular features: granulomatous or non-granulomatous uveitis
  • Primarily it is posterior uveitis and spreads to anterior

questions.text: Iritis is least associated with all of the following diseases:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

Explanation:

Iritis, also known as Anterior uveitis, is an inflammatory condition of the eye, including the iris and ciliary body.

Although SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs, iritis is less commonly seen in SLE compared to the other conditions listed. It more often causes other ocular manifestations, like dry eyes or retinal changes.

Systemic Associations and Masquerades of Iritis (Anterior Uveitis)

  • Infectious Causes:
    • Herpes Infections: Varicella Zoster, Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
    • Tuberculosis (TB)
    • Syphilis
    • Leprosy
  • Non-Infectious Causes:
    • With Systemic Association:
      • Sarcoidosis
      • Behçet's Disease (Option B ruled out)
      • HLA-B27 Associated Arthritis
      • Psoriatic Arthropathy (Option C ruled out)
      • Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Ulcerative Colitis (UC) > Crohn's Disease (Option D ruled out)
    • Without Systemic Association:
      • Drug-Induced: Pilocarpine, prostaglandin analogues
  • Masquerade Syndromes:
    • Definition: Conditions that mimic the symptoms of anterior uveitis but are not primarily inflammatory in nature.
    • Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Lymphomas
      • Anterior Segment Melanoma
      • Retinoblastoma
      • Metastasis
    • Non-Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Intraocular Foreign Body
      • Old Retinal Detachment
      • Pigment Dispersion Syndrome
      • Coats' Disease

questions.text: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option D)

Explanation

Given the farmer's symptoms of pain, discharge, and history of trauma, along with the finding of white blood cells in the anterior chamber, the most likely diagnosis is hypopyon, which often results from infection or severe inflammation following eye trauma.

 

Fungal keratitis is a common cause of corneal ulcers following eye trauma, especially when the injury is caused by vegetative matter (such as plant material or dirt). This type of trauma provides an entry point for fungal spores.

The classic signs and symptoms of fungal keratitis include:

  • Corneal ulcer with satellite lesions (smaller ulcers surrounding the main ulcer).
  • Hypopyon (accumulation of white blood cells in the anterior chamber of the eye).
  • Mild pain, photophobia, and redness.
  • The history of vegetative matter as the cause of trauma is a significant clue, as fungi are commonly found in plant material.

Keratomycosis

Clinical Features

  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering of the eye
  • Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision
  • Redness.

Examination Findings

  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry-looking with elevated, rolled-out margins.
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish appearance, possible with dematiaceous fungi.
  • Feathery Extensions: Delicate, finger-like projections into the surrounding stroma.
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation where fungal antigen and host antibodies meet.
  • Satellite Lesions: Multiple small lesions around the main ulcer.
  • Hypopyon: Large, non-sterile, even with a small ulcer.
  • Endothelial Plaque: Located under the stromal lesion, made of fibrin and leucocytes.
  • Corneal Vascularization: Typically absent in pure fungal ulcers.
  • Perforation: Rare but possible.

Investigations

  • Corneal Scraping: Performed under topical anaesthesia for microbiological examination.
  • Wet KOH Mount: Reveals filamentous fungi (branched, septate hyphae) or non-filamentous yeast-like fungi (Candida).
  • Gram's & Giemsa Stains: To detect fungal hyphae and inflammatory cells.
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar medium is used for fungal culture.
  • PCR: Recommended for rapid identification of fungal pathogens.
  • Anterior Chamber Paracentesis: Considered if there is an intraocular extension.
  • Corneal Biopsy: Indicated for deep stromal abscess or when cultures are negative.
  • Confocal Microscopy: Used for identifying actual fungi within the cornea.

Treatment of Keratomycosis (Fungal Corneal Ulcer):

Primary Treatment: Antifungal Medications:

  • Topical Antifungal Agents:
    • Natamycin
    • Voriconazole
    • Amphotericin B (effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium)
    • Nystatin (effective against Candida)
  • Oral Antifungal Agents (for severe ulcers with specific features):
    • Ketoconazole
    • Voriconazole
    • Indications for Oral Therapy:
      • Hypopyon
      • Perforation
      • Suspicion of endophthalmitis

Surgical Management (if unresponsive to medical therapy):

  • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
  • Cauterization Options:
    • Pure carbolic acid (100%)
    • Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%)
    • Povidone-iodine 5%
  • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

Hyphema (Option A): Refers to the presence of blood in the anterior chamber, often caused by trauma. While the patient did sustain trauma, the presence of pus (not blood) in the anterior chamber points to hypopyon rather than hyphema.

 

Aqueous flare (Option B): Refers to the presence of protein in the aqueous humor, which can be seen in inflammatory conditions, but it is generally seen as a cloudy appearance in the anterior chamber, not a white collection of cells like hypopyon.

 

Arlt line (Option C): This refers to a line of conjunctival scarring seen in trachoma, which is not related to the acute trauma described here and would not be associated with the findings in the anterior chamber.

questions.text:
Iritis is not seen in:


	Rheumatoid arthritis
	SLE
	Bechet’s disease
	Psoriatic arthritis
	Ulcerative colitis
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) 1 and 2

Explanation:

Conditions where iritis is seen:

  • Behcet’s disease (Statement 3 ruled out): Characterized by recurrent uveitis, including iritis, genital involvement and oral involvement.
  • Psoriatic arthritis (Statement 4 ruled out): A seronegative spondyloarthropathy frequently associated with anterior uveitis including iritis, urethritis and arthritis.
  • Ulcerative colitis (Statement 5 ruled out): Iritis is common in inflammatory bowel disease, as it shares a systemic inflammatory pathway.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: Iritis is rarely seen in adult-onset rheumatoid arthritis. However, it is more commonly associated with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), especially in ANA-positive cases.
  • SLE: Systemic lupus erythematosus typically affects other ocular tissues, such as the retina and optic nerve, rather than causing iritis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient came with complaints of blurring of vision, photophobia, redness, pain in the left eye, and joint pain. Upon examination keratic precipitates and aqueous cells were observed. Which of the following major histocompatibility complex is be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HLA B27

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of blurring vision, photophobia, redness, pain ,and keratic precipitates are suggestive of anterior uveitis. Patients with acute anterior uveitis with joint pain is suggestive of arthritis associated with uveitis. The disease affects young males who are positive for HLA B27. Among patients with ankylosing spondylitis, 90% of them belong to the HLA-B27 antigenic group.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray): Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint
  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae
  • Bamboo spine
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign
  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

HLA B51 (Option B) It is associated with Behcet's syndrome with anterior uveitis. Behcet's syndrome is characterized by bilateral recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions.

HLA B47 (Option C) Is associated with congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. It is characterized by symptoms like diarrhea, vomiting, arrhythmias, and low blood pressure.

HLA B57 (Option D) Is associated with the detection of abacavir hypersensitivity and slow progression of HIV.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a penetrating injury to the left eye was treated with corneoscleral suturing. Two months later, he returned with complaints of reduced near vision, pain, redness, and sensitivity to light in his right eye. Direct ophthalmoscopy revealed nodules in the fundus. Which part of the eye is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Uvea

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of penetrating injury to the left eye and subsequent reduced near vision, pain, redness, and photophobia along with nodules on fundus i.e., Dalen-Fuchs nodules are suggestive of Sympathetic ophthalmitis.

Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO)

Definition

Bilateral, granulomatous, panuveitis (Option A) occurring after penetrating trauma where uveal prolapse may have been a feature of the trauma

Etiology and pathogenesis
  • Trauma to one eye (exciting eye) — 2 weeks to 3 months — Uveitis in the uninjured eye (sympathizing eye).
  • T-cell mediated autoimmune hypersensitivity reaction to Retinal S antigen.
  • Maximum risk upon injury to the ciliary body.

Histopathology
  • Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the choroid.
  • Scattered aggregates of epithelioid cells are seen, many of which contain fine granules of melanin.
  • Dalen–Fuchs nodules - granulomas located between Bruch membrane and the RPE (also seen in VKH syndrome)

Clinical features
  • The exciting eye is frequently red and irritable.
  • The sympathizing eye develops irritation, blurred vision, photophobia and loss of accommodation causing difficulty in near vision (first symptom)
  • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, which may be mild or severe and is usually granulomatous

Investigations
  • Fundus exam: Dalen–Fuchs nodules, Exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis and optic disc swelling.
  • As inflammation settles, residual chorioretinal scarring may confer a ‘sunset glow’ appearance similar to VKH.
  • B-scan ultrasonography: Choroidal thickening and retinal detachment

Treatment
  • Enucleation of a severely injured eye within 10 to 14 days of the injury is effective in preventing or reducing the severity of SO
  • Steroids are the basis of initial treatment. Intravenous methylprednisolone followed by high-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months and gradually tapered according to response. Supplementary topical steroids and cycloplegics may be given

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which medication can be administered to a patient diagnosed with acute anterior uveitis, presenting with symptoms of photophobia and blurred vision?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atropine

Explanation:

Treatment for Anterior Uveitis:

  • Topical Steroids (Treatment of Choice):
    • Prednisolone: Commonly used for reducing inflammation.
    • Loteprednol: Less potential for increasing intraocular pressure.
  • Cycloplegics (Topical):
    • Rest the ciliary muscles to relieve pain.
    • Prevent and break posterior synechiae (adhesions of the iris to the lens).
    • Improve blood supply, leading to better healing.
    • Eg.:Atropine.
  • Non-Steroidal Treatment:
    • Voclosporin: Part of the Luminate program, used as a non-steroidal option.
  • For Chronic or Vision-Threatening Uveitis:
    • Monoclonal Antibodies:
      • Adalimumab: TNF-alpha inhibitor, used for severe or chronic cases.
      • Infliximab: TNF-alpha inhibitor.
    • Interferon Alpha: An option for severe cases, helps modulate the immune response.

Incorrect Options:

Moxifloxacin (Option A) is an antibiotic commonly used to treat bacterial infections.

Acetazolamide (Option C) is a medication primarily used to treat glaucoma by reducing the production of aqueous humor and lowering intraocular pressure.

Methotrexate (Option D) is an immunosuppressive medication commonly used in the treatment of various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions. It may be prescribed for severe or chronic cases of uveitis that do not respond to other treatments.

questions.text: What is the specific sign that is pathognomonic for acute anterior uveitis among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Keratic precipitates

Explanation:

Anterior Uveitis:

Definition: Most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain
  • Redness
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Serous discharge
  • Blurring and diminished vision

Examination Findings:

  • Keratic Precipitates (KPs) (Option B):
    • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes
    • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages
    • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humor; this area is known as Arlt's triangle
  • Aqueous Cells:
    • Indicator of active inflammation
  • Aqueous Flare:
    • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues
  • Muddy Iris:
    • Edema in the iris caused by protein leakage
  • Miosis:
    • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from inflamed tissue
  • Nodules on the Iris:
    • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis

Complications: (Findings)

  • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to festooned-shaped pupil
  • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma
  • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens
  • Cyclitic Membrane
  • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris

Incorrect Options:

Aqueous flare (Option A) refers to the presence of protein and inflammatory cells in the aqueous humor, which may be seen in anterior uveitis.

Festooned pupil (Option C) is a characteristic feature of posterior synechiae in chronic uveitis.

Bussaca’s nodules (Option D) are larger, granulomatous nodules that are seen in conditions like chronic anterior uveitis, especially in sarcoidosis or tuberculosis.

questions.text: An elderly female presents with sudden onset of pain, redness, and decreased vision. On examination, hazy cornea, fixed mid-dilated pupil, and shallow anterior chamber are noted. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute uveitis

Explanation:

  • The presence of ocular pain, redness, decreased vision, and corneal haze can be seen in both acute uveitis and acute angle-closure glaucoma, but here the combination of inflammation signs (ciliary congestion, corneal edema) and pupil changes points toward acute uveitis as the answer given.
  • In uveitis, cells and flare in anterior chamber cause corneal haze, and pupil is irregular or sluggishly reactive due to posterior synechiae; early on it may appear mid-dilated.
  • The shallow anterior chamber here may be due to ciliary body swelling pushing the iris forward in acute inflammation.

Key features of Acute Uveitis:

  1. Pain, photophobia, redness (ciliary flush).
  2. Decreased vision due to corneal edema and aqueous flare.
  3. Irregular or sluggish pupil (posterior synechiae).
  4. May cause shallow anterior chamber due to ciliary body congestion.

Anterior Uveitis

Definition: Most common type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye.

Clinical Features:

  • Pain
  • Redness
  • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
  • Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Serous discharge
  • Blurring and diminished vision

Examination Findings:

  • Keratic Precipitates (KPs):
    • Non-Granulomatous: Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes
    • Granulomatous: Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages
    • Location: Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humor; this area is known as Arlt's triangle

  • Aqueous Cells:
    • Indicator of active inflammation
  • Aqueous Flare:
    • Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues
  • Muddy Iris:
    • Edema in the iris caused by protein leakage
  • Miosis:
    • Constricted pupil due to toxins released from inflamed tissue
  • Nodules on the Iris:
    • Koeppe's Nodules: At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis
    • Busacca Nodules: At the base of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis

Complications: (Findings)

  • Posterior Synechiae: Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to festooned-shaped pupil

  • Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae: Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma
  • Occlusio Pupil: Covers the whole surface of the lens
  • Cyclitic Membrane
  • Rubeosis Iridis: New vessel formation on the iris

Incorrect Options:

  • Acute conjunctivitis (Option B): Presents with diffuse redness, mucopurulent or watery discharge; vision usually normal, cornea clear, pupil reactive, anterior chamber normal depth.
  • Acute congestive glaucoma (Option C): Sudden severe pain, markedly decreased vision, halos around lights, very high IOP, fixed mid-dilated pupil, shallow anterior chamber - however, it is typically more painful, with headache/nausea, and the hallmark is IOP >40 mmHg with rock-hard globe.
  • Central retinal artery occlusion (Option D): Sudden painless monocular vision loss; examination shows pale retina with cherry-red spot, no corneal haze, no anterior chamber shallowing.

questions.text: On ophthalmologic examination, the presence of Koeppe's nodules is observed in a patient diagnosed with sarcoidosis. In which area of the eye are these nodules typically observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Iris

  • Koeppe's nodules are small, yellow-white nodules that appear on the surface of the iris observed in granulomatous uveitis like sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, Vogt-Kanayagi-Harada’s disease, and sympathetic ophthalmitis . 
  • They are typically located at the pupillary margin, which is the border between the iris and the pupil. 
  • These nodules are composed of collections of inflammatory cells.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Koeppe’s nodules are present at the pupillary margin of the iris.

questions.text: Which eye condition is commonly associated with sarcoidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C

  • Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the eyes. Anterior uveitis, characterized by inflammation of the anterior chamber of the eye, is a common ocular manifestation of sarcoidosis.
  • Other Ocular Features of Sarcoidosis.
    • Sarcoid nodules on the sclera or episclera
    • Interstitial keratitis
    • Band-shaped keratopathy because of hypercalcemia.
    • Candle wax dripping: Segmental or nodular periphlebitis.
    • Lander's sign: Pre-retinal nodules.
    • Heerfordt syndrome: Sarcoidosis with uveo-parotitis.
    • Lofgren syndrome: Sarcoidosis with anterior uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, erythema nodosum.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. These ocular features are not associated with sarcoidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ocular manifestation of dengue?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cataract: 

  • "Cataract" is not an ocular manifestation typically associated with dengue fever.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Subconjunctival hemorrhage is a common ocular manifestation seen in dengue fever. It is characterized by the presence of bright red patches or spots on the white part of the eye (conjunctiva).

Option C - Uveitis: Uveitis, which refers to inflammation of the uvea, the middle layer of the eye, can occur in dengue fever. Uveitis can present with symptoms such as eye pain, redness, sensitivity to light, and blurred vision.

Option D - Retinal hemorrhage: Retinal hemorrhage can occur in dengue fever, particularly in severe cases or in the presence of associated complications like dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) or dengue shock syndrome (DSS).
